description.text:
I couldn't find a Steno machine on Thingiverse, so I made one myself. Was aiming for something like the Procat Flash, but it ended up looking a bit Xscribe - OK, not as ugly as Xscribe :)  
Uses - Key chain pendant, fridge magnet, Christmas decoration...

Use machine1.stl scale and print. I've printed it in various sizes and the detail is reasonable down to about an inch along the shortest side. 
You will need keyboard.scad, body.scad, variables.scad and buildnt.scad if you want to build it yourself. 
If you want to put text on the screen then you will need to use build.scad and make sure you have a file called writing.stl with your text in the directory when you build.

If you are like me, you upgrade your TAZ any time new improvements are announced. Lulzbot has released the TAZ 6 parts at http://devel.lulzbot.com/TAZ/Olive/ and https://ohai.lulzbot.com/group/taz-6/

I purchased my TAZ back around the AO and TAZ 1 days, so most of my mechanical parts do not match the TAZ6 parts. However, there is no reason you cannot print the improvements and enjoy the best technology offers. This "thing" contains all of the parts I used to modify my TAZ 1 up to a TAZ 5, and now a TAZ 6.

Make sure you have updated your printer to at least TAZ 5 to use these mods. Specifically, you need the hexagon hotend and the 24v system.

Basically, anything printed in blue ABS in the pictures, plus the Z probe mount, are parts that I modified for my printer.

My modifications:

  • I reduced all of the insert holes from the Lulzbot size down to 4.8mm so I could use my cheaper inserts from http://www.amazon.com/uxcell%C2%AE-M3x5mmx5mm-Threaded-Knurled-Embedded/dp/B01BHDGTQ2?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_search_detailpage
  • I added an end stop to the extruder mount on the left side. This is because the older TAZ Z axis used a lead screw that is in the area that is now occupied by the left side extruder fan. You have to move the X carriage to the right approximately 20mm.
  • I added bed corners that moved the bed 20mm to the right.
  • I added autoleveling. I didn't particularly like the 4 corner auto leveling mechanism because I've noticed my glass can bow in the middle when it is heated. I added a simple capacitive Z probe with the following parts: http://www.amazon.com/uxcell-1-10mm-Capacitance-Proximity-Sensor/dp/B00542U3M4?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_search_detailpage and http://www.amazon.com/Numato-Lab-Opto-Isolator-Breakout/dp/B00N0TKYOK?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_search_detailpage
  • I modified the stock Marlin v1.1 firmware to match my specifications of my printer. Note: my printer may not have the same parts as yours, so use at your own risk! In particular, not many people have the 1mm pitch lead screws I received on my TAZ when I bought it. You may need to change a few parameters in Marlin for it to work on your printer. That is why I am not providing a compiled firmware, so you change the values to suit your printer before you upload it. You can find the source code at https://github.com/keithjjones/Marlin/tree/TAZ6
  • I used a PEI sheet from http://www.amazon.com/Polyetherimide-Standard-Tolerance-PEI0113-Thickness/dp/B0013HQ7B0?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_search_detailpage to cover a spot on my glass that delaminated. You could probably use a thinner sheet if you do not have any problems with your bed glass. I used http://www.amazon.com/TapeCase-squares-Converted-Adhesive-Transfer/dp/B007Y7D5NQ?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_search_detailpage to stick the PEI to the glass.

As you can see, I am a sucker for Amazon Prime shipping when it is available, so I try to get all my parts off of Amazon.

I used Fusion360 (free for hobbyists!) to modify the parts.

You should need to print the modified parts for this thing, any additional parts from devel.lulzbot.com, and install the newest Marlin firmware to get started.

I also lowered the ABS bed temperature from 110C to 95C as it was burning the ABS before long prints finished. I think that is also why some prints would warp.

My results? My prints are looking 100% better than before. I am extremely impressed with the results from these modifications. Some of my ABS parts are better than PLA. ABS has always been problematic for me. I added my Cura profiles for ABS that I tweaked slightly from Lulzbot's versions.

All objects and data from Lulzbot or Marlin carry their license agreements. I just modified them for my purposes and am giving them back to the community in case anyone finds them useful.

Update 4/24/2016: I added a capacitive sensor and changed everything accordingly. This seems to work really well. This let me ditch the touch sensor technology.

Update 4/19/2016: I added the Step files in case you want to remix my work.

description.text:
UPDATE 2/10/17: A new STL is available! I finally got around to designing the hole into the "orifice" part. I have not test printed this yet, but I imagine that it will still need some light heat work to smooth out the inside of the hole (to avoid catching wool fibers).

This is my design for a spinning wheel orifice. It is not drilled but has an indicator center mark. I recommend pilot drilling at 10 degrees from vertical, then final drilling with a 5/16" bit. Heat polish to keep the wool fibers from catching on the inside of the orifice.

There is a hole made for the spindle axle. The axle will need to be epoxied into place.

Check my other files to see my 'maiden' STL file. This orifice rides inside of that maiden.

author: JasonGarf

description.text:
A little redesign of the cap holder after some suggestions of my father :)
Hoping to making it simpler and more practical. The bottom and perfectly flat face will hold the cap, even more, thanks to a sort of lip like the original thing (due to the first layer being usually more squished than the next ones); while the support, once removed, will leave a sort of grip on the attach. Supported diameters : 40.5-77mm for the common known diam. (52mm in the pictures) (If you wonder about the file name: "s" mean "support", because the initial versions were without; while "p" is for "pente" because the side is not straight for a more pleasant contact when grabbing the cap.
Here is also a 80sec. making-of the 49mm holder http://youtu.be/jQms74oR9hY )

Before print :
1) Set skeinforge for two shells and low infill, or even better if filled with shells and zero density nor solid surface to make a more flexible attach (like 15 extra shells)
2) Enable support (e.g. : Interface feed 2.0, flow 0.9, density 0.10-0.15, LTOLT 0.5, layers 0, lift 0.25; Support flow 0.7, gap 0.5, exterior only). After print (10-20min) :
3) Remove support
4) Just slide it on your strap, shirt, or anywhere else :)

comments.text: I like the simplicity of the model. Why don't you printed upside down to avoid support and have a better looking and a bit stronger  part?
comments.author: Stamos

comments.text: One thing I like about having a buckle without a gap is less of a chance in shearing the buckle.  I've broken one holder out of carelessness by yanking the strap, while the buckle was caught on something -- at least they're easy to replace.

description.text:
My first 3D model is a towel hanger created with some very much appreciated help. Original size was 24 cm wide (x) but could not export it like that so you'll have to scale it up.
GET goes on the wall while the letters of Naked are holding the towels. There are holes in the back so that you can either stick it to a surface or use the little holes in the back to hang the design on screws.
Support is needed but the MakerBot Replicator I used added very little support structure to the model. Best to print in 2 colors changing right after the top surface of GET gets closed.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I've printed it with 3 shells and 20% infill to get a strong object - I hope it's gonna endure the life of a not-so-tortured towel hanger in my flat. :)

comments.text: brilliant design, I also love the colors. how did u mount it on the wall?:)
comments.author: bonooobong

comments.text: Temporarily it's mounted on two nails but you can pull them off quite easily if you are not careful so it's not a final solution. Screws might be better but the holes should be a bit bigger for a regular screw size i think :) anyway i'd like to test the print's durability before i glue it on the door.
comments.author: bonooobong

comments.text: It's been a year and it's still intact - durability test was a success :D

description.text:
I use this to test material opacity in both flat & vertical planes when printing something that needs to be opaque (like schlem's terrapin pinhole camera).

It is 3mm thick and has two circular indentations in each face (one is 1mm deep, the other 2mm deep).

Shine a bright led type torch against the face, if you get glow anywhere, you aren't going to be light tight at the infill percentage you used. Increase & print again.

Pencil pot
Trebuchet by Claire [created on 3DTin]

Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14802 and trying to find ways to reduce the noise on my TOM, I decided to create this TOM shock absorber in the hope it would help. After all the testing was done, there was actually some reduction on the loudness of the Y stage due to less contact with the desktop where the printer is sitting :) A way to test the potential reduction is to raise the printer away from the desktop and see if it makes less noise. If it does then the dampers will help a bit. The TOM seems now ready to start moving about and with the top up like in my case is starting to resemble a wood and plastic WALL-E. :) If you have the backside spool holder ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7105 ) installed you will need to move it elsewhere as one of the back feet colides with it. The SketchUp file is included for others to tweak with it.

I sourced the springs from McMaster Carr. They are part number 9657K18 and come in a pack of 6 for USD 9.98 - the dimensions are O.D. 0.875", wire 0.091", length 3" and they are design to deflect 1.35" under the maximum load of 25 lb - so when divided by 4 springs and the TOM present weight, the travel is about 1/4".
Print 2 lefts and 2 rights. 4 pieces of the other two parts.
You may need to ream the large 10mm hole on the supports for cleanness.
Glue the heads to the marked position in the supports. I used a few drops of acetone and clamps to hold it in place for a few minutes.
Replace the lower front and back TOM 16mm screws with 20 mm and install the supports or use the countersunk versions to use the original 16mm (this is untested as I had the 20mm screws and added this version as most people will not have the 20mm screws laying around).
Insert springs in the feet and under the supports. The springs are not tightly held at the ends so if you move the TOM a lot place a little dab of hot glue inside to keep the springs in place.
Because the bottom part is not held in place like the original design, dragging the printer over the desktop may cause the springs to come out of their correct position, so do not drag the printer! :)

comments.text:
I was able to eliminate a lot of noise by cutting some of the rubber tube that comes with the ABP into
&
lt;1mm "washers" and compress them between the rods and rod covers. 6 total, one for a single end of each rod, and the difference in sound is quite significant.
comments.author: Starno

comments.text: Thanks for the great idea! I had some Sugru left over from a different project, so I rolled it into a thin sheet and punched some discs with a 3/8" piece of steel tubing. Once they cured I had silicone noise dampening discs for the rods. The drop in printer noise was immediately noticable.
comments.author: Starno

comments.text: I had tried only with some rubber foam one axis of the Y-stage (the X-stage is pretty good). I will try again with your "washers" and see if it helps.
comments.author: Starno

comments.text: With the machine I was working with, I was able to eliminate the rattle by holding onto the rods with my hands, so i figured they were not fixed well enough with just the wooden end caps.  My gut feeling was that you don't want the rod to be able to deflect back and forth, so I just compressed it against one side, but I don't have any data to back that up with.  Since some of the rod end caps are hard to access, it just made sense to do it that way at the time.

title: The ARDice - electronic dice based on Arduino

description.text:
This is a electronic game dice based on Arduino. I saw various schematics with discrete components or IOs more than twenty years ago, but this one with Arduino is easy and fun to make.

Features:

  • Random number generation (1-6), the result is displayed on LEDs in a regular 6-sided dice style.
  • Makes nice sound and animation when button is pressed.
  • Silent mode - press the button during startup to mute all sounds.
  • Sleep mode - activates after a period of inactivity.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard

Infill:

20 %

Parts needed
  • 7x 10 mm LED, any color
  • 7x 330 ohm resistor
  • 1x momentary pushbutton
  • 1x on/off rocker switch
  • 1x universal PCB 30x70 mm
  • 1x Arduino Nano or basically any Arduino.
  • 1x piezo buzzer
  • STL headers and pins
  • 1x leads for 9 V battery
  • 1x 9 V battery
  • 4x M2.5 screws
Connections

The electronics is actually pretty simple. It uses 9 digital I/O pins on the Arduino:

  • Pins D2-D8 to control LEDs
  • Pin D9 to connect the roll button
  • Pin D10 to connect the piezo buzzer

See the 123D Circuits project or the following schematics:

Breadboard view Schematic view

Step 1

Print the ARD_top.stl part first, so you can start to work on LEDs, while printing the ARD_bottom.stl part, which is bigger.

Step 2

Push the LEDs into the sockets. The part is designed to hide most of the body, leaving just the curved tip visible. You can use CA glue (superglue) or hot glue to fix them, but the friction itself should be good enough.

Solder all the cathodes (shorter leads on LEDs) together and solder a wire to them.

Step 3

Solder one 330 ohm resistor to cathode on one end and a length of wire on the other end.

Step 4

Take 8 STL pins and solder the wires to the pins. First pin is ground (the cathodes), pins 2-8 are the LEDS in the order specified in the image below (when seen from top). You can also solder directly to PCB, if you don't want to test on breadboard.

Use tape or heat shrink to isolate the leads.

LED numbering Step 5
  • Connect the STL pins to pins GND, D2-D8 of the Arduino.
  • Connect the button between pin D9 and GND.
  • Connect the buzzer between pin D10 and GND.

You can use solderless breadboard or prototyping PCB, as you like.

Test setup on breadboard (resistors are hidden under heat-shrink) Step 6

Load the TestHardware.ino sketch to Arduino and run it.

If you wired the pins correctly, the device should beep and then wait for button press. After a button press, the LEDs 1-7 should light one by one in the sequence given above and with each one shortly "click".

If you passed this test, you are basically done, you can load the ArDice_V3.ino sketch, put it all into a nice box and enjoy. The rest of steps describes the software development process for interested.

Sequential LED test Number symbols

The TestNumbers.ino sketch contains definition of number symbols. The definition is specified in binary form, as a number, where each bit corresponds to single LED. The most significant bit is ignored (is always 0 in this case), because we have only 7 LEDs, thus need only 7 bits.

The for loop in the showNumber function sets the state of each LED according to the definition of number symbol.

The sketch is very similar to TestHardware.ino, but does not blink single LEDs, but displays numbers from 1 to 6.

Number symbol test Functional dice - first version

The ArDice_V1.ino sketch is basic functional dice. Upon pressing a button, it will display animation of random numbers, finally settling on the definitive value.

We initialize random number generator by reading noise on unconnected analog pin A0. That's not the best possible solution and we should not use it for example for cryptographic purposes, but it's good enough for a game dice.

Add sleep mode with breathing

The ArDice_V2.ino sketch extends the previous version by adding timeout (30 seconds) after which the dice will 'sleep'. It will turn off the LEDs and only use the center one (LED 4, connected to pin D5) to 'breath', glow with limited and varying intensity (using PWM) to indicate the project is alive.

Add silent mode

The ArDice_V3.ino sketch is the final version. It extends the previous version by adding ability to turn off all sounds. To mute all sounds, press the button while turning on the dice

Final version

description.text:
I present my version of a frame for FPV races.

The A244 is a sturdy frame , easy to print and to replace. It's only 100 grams! with all nylon screws, alluminium spacers and camera mount.

you can mount it in 5 minutes with a screwdriver :

  • 12 * M3 nylon screws or aluminum or steel

  • 6 M3 37mm alluminium spacer (I used those of Diatone37 frame , which you can find spare parts on many sites like Hobbyking , Banggood , Aliexpress , etc.

  • 1 * M3 screw and bolt to secure camera holder with camera pin

I advise you to print with 2-3 thick layers and with an infill of 25-30 % .

This project is still in the testing phase , I will put here the needed results that I will get with this configuration :

Fc: Naze 32 SP racing F3 (cleanflight) (20$ from banggood)
Motors: DYS BE1806 2300kv (4 x 8 $ from banggood or ali express)
Propellers: 5040 KingKong (5$ for 20 pairs from banggood )
ESC : DYS 16Amps (4 x 8 from banggood or aliexpress)
Battery : 4s 1800mah (20$ from hobbyking)
FPV : ccd camera and 200mw tx with Fatshark antennas (45$ for fpv system + 55$ for eachine googles from banggood or quantum V2 from hobbyking)

WHOLE quad cost me:

about 110$ for the quad without FPV system (if you buy on aliexpress other motor and esc you can reduce it by about 25-30$)
about 200$ for the quad with FPV system and googles

NEWS

Added Rev.2 version:

  • Lighter
  • Stronger
  • With motors axis holes
  • Camera FPV support studied to hold even big cameras (max 40x40 mm)

This project is no longer a "work in progress". This is the FINAL version
Here is the video of the quad running.

https://youtu.be/YeFcycpyzKU

The frame is very stable and rigid, the quad is solid and easy to tune.

description.text:
Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice is a 2016 American superhero film featuring the DC Comics characters Batman and Superman. It is a follow-up to 2013's Man of Steel and the second installment in the DC Extended Universe. The film is directed by Zack Snyder, distributed by Warner Bros. Pictures, with a screenplay by Chris Terrio and David S. Goyer, and features an ensemble cast including Ben Affleck, Henry Cavill, Amy Adams, Jesse Eisenberg, Diane Lane, Laurence Fishburne, Jeremy Irons, Holly Hunter and Gal Gadot. Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice is the first live-action film to feature both Batman and Superman, as well as the first theatrical film to feature live-action portrayals of Wonder Woman, Aquaman, Cyborg and the Flash. In the film, the powerful alien Superman has become a controversial figure, and eccentric mastermind Lex Luthor, who is obsessed with defeating Superman, takes advantage of the animosity between Superman and Batman to produce a battle between them.

The production was announced at the 2013 San Diego Comic-Con International, after the release of Man of Steel. Snyder stated that the film would take inspiration from the Batman comic book series The Dark Knight Returns by Frank Miller, but clarified that it would follow an original premise. The incarnation of Batman in the film would also be different than the character's portrayal in the previous Batman film trilogy, serving as a cinematic reboot of the character. The film also draws influence from the "Death of Superman" story arc. Pre-production began at East Los Angeles College in October 2013, with principal photography starting in May 2014 in Detroit, Michigan. Additional filming also took place in Chicago.

Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice premiered at the Auditorio Nacional in Mexico City on March 19, 2016. It was released in the United States on March 25, 2016, in 2D, 3D, IMAX 3D, 4DX, premium large formats and 70 mm prints and is the second-highest grossing film of 2016. The film's North American and international box office openings set new records followed by a historic box office drop in its second weekend, "viewed as a disappointment because it will only make $850-$900 million worldwide." The film received a generally negative reception from the consensus of critics.

title: HTC Desire car mount on skoda octavia dashboard

description.text:
This mount was designed to be able to slide a HTC Desire cell phone in a holder and gets powered.
I also wanted the holder to be removable from the dashboard mount due to a ball-joint so it would also enables rotation of the holder.
The holder can be clicked on and off from the mount. The dashboard mount does not require drilling or glue to prevent damage.
It mounts by pushing two flat pieces between the soft parts above the radio.

The 2 parts for the mount have 2 flat pieces which needs to be bended a little after heating up, so it meets the angles of the dashboard.
This makes the mount also practically impossible to fall of. On the holder itself some little parts needs to be removed after printing, which were added to support the bridge close the the power connector.
I used some melted glue to hold the powerconnector in place. One thing I want to improve is the ball joint connection.
In some possitions it needs little more tension so I'm thinking about using a spring or something, still to be able to remove and attach the holder.
One other thing is that the hard PLA material sometimes leaves little marks on the soft HTC skin, so the holder needs some soft material inside.

title: Parametric Tool Holder for MPCNC (US or IE version)

description.text:
After following Allted's progress on his new design, I figured I will have to create a new tool holder for his design when I change to it, so I created this in preparation for that. This currently matches the dimensions of his original design.

This should give others more flexibility with making a tool holder for different diameter rotary tools. This is work in progress, so I would print a short part to test the profile of how it fits your machine before printing a full height part. The variables are well commented, but some may not be obvious what they are until you change one to see how the file is affected. It is difficult for me to come up with descriptive names for every variable. At the top of the file, I give suggestions for which variables to change for different size diameter tool holders. The program displays a previous designed part for reference so you can see if it will probably fit or not. The part I used was for reference is from my MasterGrip Tool Holder design. Any part generated from this is not guaranteed to fit, but with changing the proper variables correctly you should be able to create a wide variety of tool holders for round tools.

Let me know if you have a question or see a problem in my code.

This is the best, most practical, and simplest filament manager I've seen or used for a Prusa Mendel. It gets the filament reels out of the way into "unused" space above the printer, allows you to stage two reels for easy switching back and forth, and makes it simple to change reels and to see how much filament is left. When printing, the filament itself is in free air between the reel and the extruder head so there are no jams or problems.
Also great for dual extruder printers.
Holds from 1lb to 5lb standard filament reels.
Note: You can add this Nylock Nut Knob to this thing to allow toolless filament changes.

You can make either a metric (8mm) or imperial (5/16) version. Imperial is easier to source in the US.
Parts list:
  • Pair of printed filament spool hubs in the correct size (see below).
  • 1 printed frame vertex.
  • 20" or 50cm length of threaded rod (5/16 or 8mm).
  • 8 flat washers (5/16 or 8mm).
  • 6 regular hex nuts (5/16 or 8mm).
  • 2 Nylock nuts (5/16 or 8mm). (Nylock nuts have little nylon inserts that hold the nut in place on the shaft unless you force them to turn with a wrench. Any good hardware store should stock them. Most ACE hardware stores stock the 5/16 size.)
    • Print the filament spool hubs and the frame vertex (which serves as a mount). You can also use the vertex from the Prusa Mendel Lamp Mount, and get the option of adding a gooseneck light. Download and print the PDF file. Bend the length of threaded rod as shown in the PDF drawing. Dimensions are not critical (my drawing program shows too much resolution). A bench vise will make this easy, but you can get creative with vise grips or other tools to make the simple bends needed. Be sure not to damage the threads in the areas you'll be putting nuts on. Cut any excess with a hacksaw if needed. You can use these vise pads I made at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13948 to hold the rod for bending. Mount the frame vertex in the spare space on the top 2 rods of your Prusa Mendel. Use washers and regular nuts as needed. Mount the threaded rod in the frame vertex using additional washers and regular nuts. Get everything really tight. The horizontal portion of the rod should now be above the printer and level with the floor. Make adjustment bends if needed. Put one Nylock nut on the horizontal part of the threaded rod and crank it on a few inches with a wrench. Put on a flat washer, and one of the hubs. Put your filament spool on (with the filament unreeling towards the center, directly above the extruder), the other hub, another washer, and the final Nylock nut. Tighten the last nut until everything is snug, then loosen it slightly until the reel turns easily but with a very slight drag (so the filament doesn't unspool wildly). This is where you want it. Feed the filament into your extruder and you're ready to go. Repeat the above for a second reel mount if you want.

There doesn't seem to be much of a standard for the size of the hole in filament spools. I've encountered four distinct sizes, and made hubs for each of them. I've compiled a list of which filaments use which hub diameter.
  • 18.75mm: Taulman's small (1 pound?) filament spools
  • 38mm: Ultimachine large (5 pound) spools
  • 50mm: Most common size. Used for 1kg spools from Makerbot, Ultimachine, and Protoparadigm.
  • 72mm: Unknown. I seem to have thrown away whatever spool I printed this for.
    • I make no guarantees this list is accurate, as manufacturers seem to commonly change the size they use. In fact, it's probably better to just measure the hole diameter and print the corresponding hub, if you can.

title: Lewihe Play base for TR8x8 leadscrew and nut

description.text:
SPANISH: (See below for English)
Vi el diseño que los chicos de Lewihe publicaron aqui para usar en la base una tuerca miniatura y me gustó, gracias chicos!. De cualquier modo tenía por aquí unos husillos TR8x8 y unas tuercas que me hicieron pensar: ¿porque no? Como no pude encontrar ningun diseño de la base me hice mi propia versión. Necesitarás 4x tornillos M3x16mm, 4x tuercas M3, El husillo y la tuerca TR8x8, y una transmisión de 5 a 8mm. Me parece una actualización muy chula porque odio las feas y ruidosas varillas M5. Creedme cuando digo que una vez hecha la actualización, esta impresora dejará de parecer un juguete... Dejo aqui mi diseño FreeCAD por si acaso necesitais ajustar algo para vuestra configuración. Recordad que teneis que modificar los pasos del eje Z en el marlin para que sean 400 pasos/mm ya que los husillos TR8x8 corren 8mm por vuelta. Este diseño es similar a ese tan chulo que los chicos de Lewihe han puesto aquí, mi diseño es en cambio simple y basto como yo.

Nota: Cuando busqué las especificaciones de la tuerca TR8x8 figuraba que los agujeros para los tornillos eran M4. Así que diseñé la pieza así. Cuando me llegaron las tuercas solo cabían tornillos M3 y me las tuve que ingeniar para poner tornillos M3 (fácil). He dejado un diseño nuevo para tornillos M3 y he actualizado el .STL.

(UPDATE 24-MAY-2016): Pequeño fillet para hacer más fácil el uso de tornillos inferiores para el ajuste de la altura de la cama.

ENGLISH:
I saw the part that the guys at Lewihe provided here to use a miniature nut spindle and I loved it, thank you guys!. Anyway I had liying around some TR8x8 leadscrews and nuts and that made me think why not? As I couldn't find any design of the base I made my own version. You will need 4x M3x16 screws, 4x M3 nuts, a TR8x8 nut and leadscrew, and a transmision adapter 5x8. It is a cool update for me, because I hate that ugly and noisy M5 rods. Believe me when I say that once made this change, this printer will never look like a toy anymore... I post here my FreeCAD sources just in case you need some adjustment to your setup. Remember that you have to modify your marlin setup to have 400 step/mm for the Z axis as the TR8x8 rods runs 8mm each turn. This design is similar to the nice one the Lewihe's guys published here. Anyway my design is simple and coarse like me.

FYI: When I was looking for the TR8x8 nut specs I found that the holes were M4, so I designed this thing accordingly. Unfortunately when my nuts arrived only M3 bolts fitted in the holes and I had to manage to use them (no problem). I redesigned the part to fit M3 screws and updated the .STL also.

(UPDATE 24-MAY-2016): Added a little fillet to ease the use of inferior bolts to adjust bed's height.

a coworker wanted a tool to use for his upcoming fence project, he needed to be able to quickly locate the center of the top of a 4x4 post and mark it for drilling. a quick bit of google taught me that most posts are 3.5x3.5 but not always, so i made the center of this piece at 3.5x3.5 inches and the outer inside perimeter at 4x4 inches with a 1/2 inch hole int he center.

hope it helps someone else.

description.text:
I just made this so I could see the percentage of shrinkage for holes in designs. The ruler should be 3mm thick.

If you remix this or make alterations, please upload them back with all original solid works files so that everyone can use them, and people that don't have solid works can then benefit from the modifications,
Thanx

I Always add the original creation file not just the stl, so if people want to play with the design they can.

OK Folks, my apologies for not getting this out before Christmas Day, but I was, you know, Resolving Issues.
This is the solution for the late, forgetful, busy, or uninspired gift giver.  Good ol' cash is always welcome, and this provides a cool way to present it and show off your 3D printing prowess.
The ellipse is sized to match the portrait on recent US currency.  There is a slot at the bottom for sliding in a folded bill (or two or three), and an attachment point at the top for a hanger hook.

This can be a challenging print due to the ellipse which requires bridging, and the high, narrow aspect ratio.  It is probably advisable to rotate it so that the long side is aligned with the direction the bed moves...though I had successes and failures in both orientations.
Failures occurred when the tips of the incomplete ellipse warped upwards and contacted the moving printhead, knocking the thing over.  Something is different in the latest Slic3r (0.5.7) such that this did not happen.
I used default settings on Slic3r, excepting 0.1 fill density, concentric infill and 235 C nozzle temp.
I used a Prusa with a bed heated to 90 C.  Base material was PET tape lightly smeared with acetone-dissolved ABS.  I used black ABS only because that is all I have on hand at the moment.
A utility or hobby knife is recommended to clean up the bridged area of the ellipse.

print_settings.Notes:: If your printer has strong enough supports, use final product litwick. If it's a cheaper not so great one, use the litwick candle holder 2 stl.

description.text:
Here is a Litwick candle holder based on the original design from Pokemon. Created, painted, and printed this in order to give it a more realistic look. For candles anything around 1.5 inches in diameter will fit in but the depth has to be pretty small. I've always loved ghost pokemon so making this was a really fun process.

If your printer has strong enough supports, use final product litwick. If it's a cheaper not so great one, use the litwick candle holder 2 stl.

I'll post a pic of my previous models here too just cause litwicks are cuter together. Hope you like it.

Printer:

Fortus 250

Infill:

60%

Notes:

I used a 60% infill on my final one but for my prototypes i used 30% and they just turned out alright. I would recommend 60% or higher infill for best results.

If your printer has strong enough supports, use final product litwick. If it's a cheaper not so great one, use the litwick candle holder 2 stl.
Print out the stl Buy suitable paint for your print. I used acrylic paint for mine. Paint it! Yay! Happy Litwick! Maybe make it some friends!

comments.text: You're going to need to fix the model, there's a massive hole above the eye, and the side close to the arm, and a small one on the mouth. IT doesn't seem that bad on the thingiview but it shows up when printing.
comments.author: Akuroku813

description.text: This is a corner bracket designed to attach three 2.5mm panels at right angles to each other.

You will benefit from cutting a 10mm square notch out of the corners of the panels, in order to fit properly. These were designed for attaching laser-cut panels of thin acrylic, so the cut can be integrated into a pretty simple SVG.
This is a simple hanger. I made this with laser cutting in mind, but you can 3D print it just as easy.
Wheel

author: MrPenguin

title: Metalebkuchen
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: MY FIRST EVER THINGIVERSE UPLOAD, yaaaaaay!! 2-part biscuit/cookie cutter featuring (a derivate of) the logo of Metalab, our super awesome hackerspace. :) -> https://metalab.at/ "Metalebkuchen" is a play on words combining Metalab & Lebkuchen, which is the German word for gingerbread. I haven't yet tested the cutter on actual gingerbread dough (which I've heard is a PITA to work with), but I already made regular biscuits with them yesterday & today and they turned out great! FR:
Réplique de la clé PTT passe-partout T10 utilisé par les facteurs, le modèle est basée uniquement à partir de scans et de photo de ma HNE3.
Aucune mesure ou prise d'empreinte, c'est la même technique qui a été utilisé pour dupliqué les passe-partout TSA.

Je ne recommande néanmoins pas de la produire dans le but de l'essayé sur un cylindre de boite au lettre (c'est du plastique, ça casse facilement, et vous aurez sûrement besoin de la poncé un peut, du moins ça dépendra de votre maîtrise de l'imprimante)
Bref gardé la pour vos collecs, c’est plus simple.

EN:
T10 master key i did a while ago for the pleasure of increasing my 3D master keys collection.
Originally, this key is used by French postmans to open letterboxes.

I don't recommend using it on your letterbox due to plastic who tend to break easily and as it's also a question of printer settings, sanding etc.., so keep it as a prop it's more simple.
May only the challenge guide you to print a working one :)

This reproduction is based only from pictures of my key, same process who got used for duplicating the TSA master keys.

author: barrstudent

title: Harbor Breeze Fan Remote Control Holder

description.text:
For the ceiling fan in our bedroom, I wanted to leave the wall switch on at all times and only control the fan and built in light with the remote.  The switch is right by the door so we'd normally walk in and, without thinking, hit the switch to turn it on or off.  I knew it would take us forever to break the habit of not using the switch and the tape I previously had over it just looked bad.  3D printer to the rescue!  
This Thing both blocks the switch from being accidentally turned on and off, but also serves as a holder for the remote.  It's a nice tight fit for the remote so it doesn't move around as you're pressing the control buttons.  You can still reach in from either side to flip the switch if needed.  
The light switch itself in our house is slightly recessed behind the existing wall plate so the existing screws were too short.  Yours may work fine, but I substituted a couple of light switch screws (used to mount another switch I'm not using) and dipped the ends in white paint to match the wall plate.  Works great!

I printed this on my Solidoodle 2.0 with 0.2 infill and supports.  I rotated the part on the print bed using Repetier Host so that the supports would be easier to remove.  You can see the orientation of the support structure in the photo of the part on the print bed.

title: T-Slot Filament Spool holder M8 and American Standard Size

description.text:
This spool holder will let you use larger spools in addition to smaller spools. Our local stores don't stock M8 threaded rods, so I decided to support common American-size threaded rods and nuts in addition to Metric. Required hardware: Dual Setup: (see picture)
1x 3/8 threaded rod, 10 inch
8x 9/16 nuts
6x 3/8 washers 4x Spool_caps
1x Spool_holder_body
1x feed_tube_spinner
1x feeder *for M8 setup, replace all hardware with M8 nuts, washers, and rods! *Study Fig. 1! The "Jam Nuts" prevent the inner caps from moving, while the "Adjusting Nuts" tighten the spools. You need your spools loose so they can rotate freely. When adjusted properly, the "Jam Nuts" will prevent your spools from being over tighten. No nut required on spool holder body in a dual spool setup, which makes servicing both spools by removing either cap.

author: ArcherEG

print_settings.Notes:: This resolution and infill combo seems to be totally sufficient for the PLA I printed with.  Time will tell if I should have gone with more infill, but if you do 4+ shells, and 4+ top and bottom layers, the amount of infill doesn't matter too much, since the walls of the thing aren't THAT thick. It's effectively solid.

description.text:
I don't know how it happened... but one of the hinge pins on my recycling bin disappeared. I suspect that my son may have had something to do with this.

In any case, I had one pin left, and own a 3d printer...

Printer:

Monoprice Dual Extruder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This resolution and infill combo seems to be totally sufficient for the PLA I printed with. Time will tell if I should have gone with more infill, but if you do 4+ shells, and 4+ top and bottom layers, the amount of infill doesn't matter too much, since the walls of the thing aren't THAT thick. It's effectively solid.

First things first, I whipped out the micrometer and measured the hell out of the OEM pin.

Once I had a good set of measurements, I opened up Autodesk 123D Design, and started laying down the parts. The flare on the shaft of the pin, near the cap, seemed like it flared out a little, so I replicated that using stacked cones.

description.text: This bracket is used to mount a 25mm Pole against a wall or inside a cabinet.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

80%

Notes:

In order to carry a bit of weight, this bracket needs to be strong. I recommend using atleast 80% infill and printing with ABS.

I've also used 3mm Brim to prevent warping.

Use 10mm x 5mm Tapered Head Screws and some double-sided tape to mount the bracket to a surface. Here I've installed a paper towel rail inside one of my kitchen cabinets. The paper towel roll weighs about 5 kilograms. Here I've installed a paper towel rail inside one of my kitchen cabinets. The paper towel roll weighs about 5 kilograms.

remixed_from.author: waagstrom
remixed_from.title: 3M Style Respirator Filter Bayonet Style Male Mount

description.text:
Required a Bayonet connector for a respirator mod I was working. Couldn't find anything, so designed my own! Used Waagstrom's Male connector as a quick reference and visual guide.

Recommend printing mostly solid, with supports. The pins are rather small, though it can be incorporated a few ways, which provide more support to them.

I've attached the STL and Autodesk 123D file. Might have to take off a bit of the inside, depending on design.
